US President Trump tweeted that it is not acceptable that China levies a 16% tax on soybeans and Canada imposes limits on agricultural products. He then accused Mexico, China, Canada and others of treating US farmers “unfairly” and stated that things will change by the time trade talks come to an end. (Twitter/ Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

At the ASCO conference over the weekend, where many healthcare names provided updates/results on their studies, Merck (MRK) announced significant improvements for its Keytruda cancer drug, and accordingly outperformed the healthcare sector on Monday. However, Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) and Bristol Myers Squibb (BMY) released data on its cancer immunotherapy which saw mixed results, resulting in NKTR hitting intraday lows of ~40%, and BMY lower by 5%. Retailers performed well today with Walmart (WMT) acquiring a majority stake in Walmart Brazil, subject to regulatory approval, where it forecasts a slight benefit to EPS next fiscal year, WMT led the DJI today with gains of roughly 2.5%. Over in the SPX Under Armour (UA) and target (TGT) outperformed also. Apple (AAPL) rose to fresh intraday record highs before its worldwide Developers Conference, and traders booked profits. At the WWDC CEO Tim Cook said Apple has paid out USD 30bln to iPhone app developers in the last year; total developer earnings from the tech giant are expected to hit USD 100bln this week. Treasuries were lower on Monday as political turmoil settled in Europe following last week’s events in Italy and Spain. PREVIEW: RBA Rate decision due on 5 June 2018 at 0530 BST
content:
•  
  •  
  • RBA rate decision to be published on 5 June at 0530 BST/0030 EDT
  • RBA expected to hold its Cash Rate at 1.50%; market reaction expected to be limited

EXPECTATIONS: The RBA rate decision is due on Tuesday morning, and expectations are one-sided for the central bank to keep policy on hold. This has been reflected in the ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures,  which price in 100% expectations for the central bank to keep the Cash Rate Target unchanged at the record low 1.50%, while the associated implied yield curve suggests June 2019 as the earliest date for when the central bank would be leaning more towards a 25bps rate hike.

RECENT RHETORIC: The rhetoric from the central bank continues to point to no near-term policy adjustments; the latest central bank Statement on Monetary Policy and minutes from the prior meeting reiterated that the board sees no strong case for a near-term change in rates, and that the next move would likely be a hike rather than a cut. The RBA also expects inflation to remain subdued for some time due to retail competition and slow growth in wages. This view on rates has been continuously repeated by the top echelon at the bank, including Governor Lowe and Deputy Governor Debelle, while board member Harper also suggested that the Bank has a ‘steady as she goes’ stance on policy, and that a recovery in wage growth will be a long haul.

RECENT ECONOMIC DATA: Q1 Wage Price was softer than expected at 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%) which limits scope for the RBA to begin hiking rates considering the central bank has cited slow wages as a factor for the subdued inflation. In addition, Capital Expenditure for Q1 (0.4% vs. Exp. 1.0%) and Building Approvals for April (1.9% vs. Exp. 4.1%) have also fallen short of estimates. Conversely, jobs data was more encouraging with better than expected Employment Change (Apr) 22.6k vs. Exp. 20.0k (Prev. 4.9k, Rev. -0.7k) and although the unemployment rate unexpectedly increased, this coincided with a higher Participation Rate and there was an overall better quality of jobs growth as it was solely fuelled by Full-Time work. There was also more recent data released at the start of the week in which Retail Sales, Company Profits and Business Inventories topped estimates which could provide some encouragement ahead of the GDP number this Wednesday.

MARKET REACTION: The announcement is scheduled for 0530BST and is not expected to have a major impact on markets with the RBA unanimously expected to keep policy on hold as they have been doing since 2016. However, participants will still be eyeing the policy statement for any deviation from the central banks regular statements.

RECENT BANK CALLS: CBA pushed back forecasts for RBA rate hike to February 2019 from Prev. forecast of November 2018. NAB pushed back RBA rate hike forecast to mid-2019 from Prev. forecast of November 2018.

UBS weekly FX flows: SEK recorded inflows for the first time in 5 weeks; EUR sold for a 9th week
content:
• EURUSD: EURUSD recorded inflows, as buying by private clients and asset managers outweighed marginal selling by hedge funds and corporate clients. 
  • USDJPY, EURJPY: USDJPY was net bought, as all client groups registered inflows, led by asset managers. EURJPY was sold, as all client groups sold the pair except for private clients who were marginal buyers. 
  • GBPUSD, EURGBP: GBPUSD experienced inflows, as buying by asset managers and private clients outweighed selling by hedge funds and corporates. GBP recorded outflows vs EUR, as all client groups were GBP sellers except for asset managers. 
  • EURCHF, USDCHF: CHF was sold vs EUR for the fourth straight week as asset manager inflows were overwhelmed by selling from other client groups. USDCHF recorded outflows, as all client groups except hedge funds sold the pair.
  • AUDUSD, NZDUSD, and USDCAD: AUDUSD saw strong inflows for a fourth straight week as hedge funds led all client groups in buying interest. NZDUSD was net bought for the first time in six weeks as all client groups registered buying interest except for corporates, who showed limited directionality. USDCAD was net bought, as hedge fund and private client buying outweighed marginal selling by corporate clients. 
  • EURSEK, EURNOK, USDSEK, and USDNOK: EURSEK saw historically strong outflows as selling was dominated by asset managers and hedge funds while private clients showed limited directionality. EURNOK was marginally bid as all the client group flows were more or less flat. USDSEK registered outflows for the first time in nine weeks driven mostly by asset managers, while corporate and private clients showed limited directionality. NOK recorded outflows vs USD, led almost entirely by asset managers.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 4 June 2018: Risk tone firm ahead of ‘G6+1’ meeting this week; tech shares print fresh record highs
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, DXY soft, Crude down.
* REAR-VIEW: Trump doubles-down on tough trade talk; US Factory Orders miss; UK Construction PMI surprise beat.
* AHEAD: RBA Rate Decision, Chinese, Japanese Services PMI overnight // EZ & UK Services PMI, US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI, BoE's Cunliffe, ECB’s Weidmann to speak, API inventories on Tuesday.

* TRADE WARS: Early in the session, US President Trump tweeting that it is “Not acceptable!” that China levies a 16% tax on soybeans and Canada imposes limits on agricultural products. He then accused Mexico, China, Canada and others of treating US farmers “unfairly” adding that things will change by the time trade talks come to an end. Trump also stated that the US can only win after so many years of bad trade deals. EU Trade Chief Malmstrom said the EU is examining safeguards of steel and aluminium and said the first measures could take place in July; she added US car tariffs would be very unfortunate, with potentially even bigger EU counter measures than in steel and aluminium. Malmstrom also claimed that if the US wants to stop the WTO dispute system, they are on the right path, adding that the US has not been willing to work with the EU on this matter. Malmstrom also floated that there could be a possible ‘Plan B’ to unblock WTO dispute settlement, but stated they are not there yet. UK PM May spokesperson said PM May told US President Trump they are seeking an EU wide exemption on tariffs whilst UK Trade Minister Liam Fox said the response to US tariffs must be examined, adding the UK is to take safeguard measures to prevent steel dumping in the country, which could be in place by the middle of July. Elsewhere, Mexico announced it will start a dispute settlement process at the WTO over tariffs. Finally, ECB’s Nowotny, at the EU conference in Vienna, did not touch on monetary policy but urged the EU to be united on trade issues.

* BOE SPEAK: BoE’s Tenreyo (Neutral) said a few rate rises are needed, though the timing is an open question; she expects gradual tightening of monetary policy will be need over the next three years. Only a slight tweak in language from her previous comments, but not leaning back on the notion of tigher policy ahead, she added that weakness in UK economy in Q1 likely to be erratic but does raise the possibility of some underlying weakness in demand. Likely FX pass through effect on inflation will fade slightly faster than expected, Tenreyro believes, arguing that a tightening of UK labour market is likely to lead to an increase in domestic cost pressures. Future policy changes can act as substitutes for immediate change, she said, and on recent political events, Tenreyro suggested that the uncertainties in Europe mean that the BoE must remain watchful. She said it is too early to say, when asked about signals coming from UK economic data since the MPC meeting in May.

* BREXIT: UK PM May is said to have told business leaders a decision on the preferred customs option post-Brexit was 'imminent', sources reported; some business leaders said a frictionless border was more important than tariffs, after the UK leaves the EU, adding they need to be able to add foreign labour following the exit. The In early trade, it was announced the EU withdrawal bill is expected to come back to the Commons on June 12th at 12.30BST.

* SPX +0.4% , NDX +0.9%, DJI +0.7%. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +1.1%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: 0.8%, Energy: -0.9%, Financials: +0.3%, Health Care: +0.4%, Industrials: -0.1%, Materials: +0.6%, Telecoms: -0.1%, Tech: +0.8%, Utilities: -0.9%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: At the ASCO conference over the weekend, where many healthcare names provided updates/results on their studies, Merck (MRK) announced significant improvements for its Keytruda cancer drug, and accordingly outperformed the healthcare sector on Monday. However, Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) and Bristol Myers Squibb (BMY) released data on its cancer immunotherapy which saw mixed results, resulting in NKTR hitting intraday lows of ~40%, and BMY lower by 5%. Retailers performed well today with Walmart (WMT) acquiring a majority stake in Walmart Brazil, subject to regulatory approval, where it forecasts a slight benefit to EPS next fiscal year, WMT led the DJI today with gains of roughly 2.5%. Over in the SPX Under Armour (UA) and target (TGT) outperformed also. Apple (AAPL) rose to fresh intraday record highs before its worldwide Developers Conference, and traders booked profits. At the WWDC CEO Tim Cook said Apple has paid out USD 30bln to iPhone app developers in the last year; total developer earnings from the tech giant are expected to hit USD 100bln this week. He also noted the new iOS 12 operating system will focus on performance, including battery life and quicker apps access.

* M&A NEWS: Relatively light today but we did get an update regarding Monsanto (MON) and Bayer (BAYN GY) where the latter announced a USD 7bln cash call in order to finance its USD 62.5bln takeover of Monsanto, and it is said to close the deal on Thursday this week. 

* WTI FUTURES (JUL 2018) SETTLE USD 1.06 LOWER AT USD 64.75/BBL, BRENT FUTURES (AUG 2018) SETTLE USD 1.50 LOWER AT USD 75.29/BBL. Oil price prices started the week on the back foot amid continued rising crude production rates in the US and after the unofficial OPEC+ meeting over the weekend in Kuwait continued to signal an unwillingness to ease restrictions, with members and non-members agreeing on the need to balance global oil supply (NOTE: Russia – who has called for supply curbs to be eased – was not present). On Monday, Russia’s economy minister said he sees crude averaging between $65-$70 this year; meanwhile, Russian oil production was unchanged in May at around 10.97mln BPD; recent reports have also suggested that Rosneft has been testing lifting its crude supply by 70k BPD, in the event that supply restrictions are lifted. Elsewhere, Iran oil exports have hit a post-sanctions era high of 2.7mln BPD in May, according to reports; Iran has added over 1mln BPD barrels of supply when sanctions were lifted in 2015. In analyst chatter, volatility is likely to remain in place in the next three weeks ahead of the official OPEC+ meeting in Vienna on June 22nd where output cuts will be in focus, analysts at PVM said. Goldman Sachs said strong oil demand continued in March at 2.6% YY, above its forecast for 1% YY.  Goldman continues to forecast 1.8mln BPD growth in 2018, above IEA forecast of 1.4mln BPD. Analysts forecast crude stocks will draw by 2.5mln in the week; Cushing stocks are seen building by 210k (from 29/May) and a draw of around 70k (from 25/May); products are seen building in the week, by 800k and 400k for distillate and gasoline, respectively.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (SEP 2018) SETTLED 11 TICKS LOWER AT 119-26+. Treasuries were lower on Monday as political turmoil settled in Europe following last week’s events in Italy and Spain. Yields were higher but off their multi-year peaks as trade fear remains in investors’ minds. Volume in the complex was average in a quiet session; the yield curve saw some modest bear flattening with 2yr and 5yr yields higher by c.4bps and 30yr higher by c.3bps, but major spreads across the curve were pretty much unchanged at settlement.

* USD: Some suggested it was trade concerns weighing on the buck, others suggested that the generally better risk tone was the driver, while there was also talk of booking some of the post-payroll profits. Next week’s FOMC is now coming into focus, where the central bank is expected to hike the FFR corridor by 25bps; however, attention will be on the terminal rate, which is likely to be a bigger driver of the USD. 

* EUR: now that the mini Eurozone crisis seems to have abated, the theme is ‘stabilisation’, with many desks now suggesting that lows seen last week above 1.15 may be a short-term bottom. The single currency was happy to range between around 1.1650-1.1750 in Monday trade, though the bias was to the downside when US traders for to their desks; stops have been cited above the range. In terms of Monday’s drivers, there was little after a dismal Sentix report, with the analyst community more focussed on Angela Merkel’s vision for European reforms going forward, which do not seem as aggressive as those outlined by French President Macron last year; Commerzbank has suggested now that the euphoria that followed EUR after Macron won last year looks unjustified, and it is time for FX markets to begin pricing this out of the currency.

* GBP: Brexit headlines are now back in fashion, with the UK set to unveil its white paper on its desired relationship with the EU “imminently” according to reports on Monday. It was also announced that the EU Withdrawal Bill will come back to the lower House next week (12/Jun), a session where some 15 amendments will be discussed. On Monday, the slide in GBP stabilised around 1.33; some are beginning to note that sterling has fallen a long way over the last couple of months without any notable retracement, and some have suggested the ‘buy-the-dip’ region may sit around 1.33. Comments from BOE’s Tenreyro in late European trade did little to help sterling bounce, as she more-or-less maintained her stance that policy is contingent on incoming data, and there is still scope for patience.

* JPY: The yen was sold overnight after decent Aussie data, helping risk sentiment following a solid payrolls report last week. The 109.75-80 region has been touted as key resistance, and for the most part, it behaved so on Monday. A break opens the way to the 200dMA around 110.20, and then to 111.00, technicians say. Action in EURCHF has been more dogged, with the pair consolidating around the 1.15 region.

* AUD: The antipodeans put in a solid shift on Monday, with the Aussie breaking through resistance at around 0.7650 after solid retail sales overnight. Overnight, the RBA policy meeting is likely to be a snooze fest, with money markets seeing no action for the central bank until the second half of next year.

* MXN: The EMFX was performing well amid a firmer risk tone, with the exception of the Mexican peso, which was the notable underperformer in the complex. The weakness came as a result of a double-whammy of unfavourable NAFTA developments (Trump’s comments about doing a deal with Mexico and Canada separately – comments made last week – continue to add uncertainty as the viable window to reaching a deal gets narrower) as well as election polls (AMLO’s poll lead has extended and he is now polling at 50%, according to one poll, up from 46%; support for the more market friendly Anaya, meanwhile, slipped).

* COMING-UP: RBA RATE DECISION TO BE PUBLISHED ON 5 JUNE AT 0530 BST/0030 EDT. RBA is expected to hold its cash rate at 1.50%; market reaction expected to be limited. Expectations are one-sided for the central bank to keep policy on hold. This has been reflected in the ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures, which price in 100% expectations for the central bank to keep the Cash Rate Target unchanged at the record low 1.50%, while the associated implied yield curve suggests June 2019 as the earliest date for when the central bank would be leaning more towards a 25bps rate hike.

* CENTRAL BANK OF TURKEY RATE DECISION TO BE PUBLISHED ON 7 JUNE AT 1200 BST. The consensus view expects the CBT to hold its one-week repo rate at 16.50%, after its recent tweaks to its policy framework, where it has made the benchmark rate its one-week repo rate (previously it was the late liquidity window), hiking the rate by 300bps to 16.50%, and keeping a symmetric overnight corridor around the repo-rate of 150bps for the overnight borrowing and lending rates. Even after an emergency rate hike and a ‘simplification’ of its policy framework, some analysts continue to expect rates to be lifted further, as the central bank attempts to regain its inflation targeting credibility, and bring inflation of nearly 13% YY to its 5% target.

subject: BNP Paribas asset management update; Cut longs in European Equities and cuts German Bunds to neutral due to risks in Italy
content:
• Cut long position in European equities following political risks in Italy

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Aussie rules, but Greenback claws back some lost ground
content:
USD

The Dollar remains on the back foot amidst a broad upturn in risk sentiment, but the DXY has recovered off worst levels towards 93.900 from sub-93.700 at one stage as key levels in several Usd pairings hold or are tested, but respected and rejected.

AUD

Extended overnight gains and outperformance through a key Fib (0.7660) vs its US counterpart at one stage, but then lost some traction on the aforementioned general Greenback grind off the lows, and perhaps some position paring/profit taking ahead of the RBA policy meeting (full preview available via our headline feed) and GDP data on Wednesday. Aud/Usd currently around 0.7650 vs a circa 0.7665 peak and 0.7555 pre-Aussie data low.

NZD

The Kiwi has gradually unwound some of its underperformance vs the Aud as the cross drifts down from the high 1.0800 area and Nzd/Usd nudged up towards 0.7050.

EUR

The next best G10 currency and advancing further above 1.1700 to pick off some spec offers at 1.1740, but holding below 1.1750 amidst more supply said to be layered and with 1.1752 representing a key Fib, while 1.1751 also forms resistance on a daily chart. Note, stops above 1.1760 remained untouched as a result.

CAD/CHF

The Loonie and Franc are also ending firmer vs the Usd, and the former tested 1.2900 despite more critique from the US over Canada’s policies and behaviour over lumber and dairy exports. Usd/Chf has slipped back towards the base of a 0.9830-95 range.

GBP/JPY

Narrowly mixed vs the Dollar, with Cable unable to breach 1.3400 in wake of a 2nd UK PMI beat as the construction headline masked weak new orders, while Usd/Jpy remained relatively rangebound between 109.35-75 and flanked by hefty option expiries either side (108.90-109.05/110.00).

TRY/SEK/NOK

All relatively strong, with the Lira inflated by rising Turkish price data (headline and core CPI, plus PPI) that could see the CBRT hike rates this week against the consensus for the new official 1 week repo to remain unchanged (see headline feed for more on Thursday’s policy meeting). Usd/Try around 4.6000. Meanwhile, the Scandi crowns both appreciated vs the Eur again on relative Riksbank/Norges Bank hawkishness vs the ECB, with Eur/Sek down around 10.2500 and Eur/Nok near 9.5000, but with the latter potentially carrying upside seasonal risks due to tight bank liquidity during June.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 4th June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities are positive (Stoxx 600 +0.6%) as markets continue to digest Friday's NFP report and the rescheduling of the NK-US summit on June 12th
  • US Commerce Secretary Ross travelled to Beijing the past weekend for the 3rd round of trade talks with China which ended without a deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US factory orders, ECB’s Nowotny and BoE’s Tenreyro

 

TRADE

US Commerce Secretary Ross travelled to Beijing the past weekend for the 3rd round of trade talks with China which ended without a deal. However, there were comments by Ross that meetings were friendly and frank, while China commented that they have made concrete progress but warned any action by US to impose punitive tariffs would derail the negotiations. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow stated that Canadian PM Trudeau’s response to the US tariffs on steel and aluminium was an overreaction, while he added the tariffs may last a while or not which is subject to negotiations and that he views the issue as more of a family quarrel. (Newswires)

Canada launched WTO and NAFTA cases on US metal tariffs. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week higher across the board as the region got a double-dose of optimism from stronger than expected US NFP jobs data and after US President Trump confirmed the summit with North Korea will go ahead as initially planned in Singapore on June 12th. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) were both positive from the get-go with CYBG shares leading the advances in Australia after the Co. sweetened its merger bid for Virgin Money, while the Japanese benchmark was among the outperformers as it coat-tails on a weaker currency. Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) also conformed to the broad upbeat sentiment following a net liquidity injection by the PBoC and amid reports that China widened the collateral for its Medium-term Lending Facility which will include qualified credit bonds. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid a similar performance in T-notes and with demand subdued by risk appetite, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement also failed to support as the central bank maintained its purchase amounts across the curve.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day and CNY 20bln via 28-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4208 (Prev. 6.4078)

Australian Retail Sales MM (Apr) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.0%). (Newswires)

Australian Gross Operating Company Profits (Q1) 5.9% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 2.2%)

Australian Business Inventories (Q1) 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.2%)

 

EU/UK/US

Britain will have only weeks to negotiate deals with dozens of countries after the European Union denied help to extend any existing trade agreements before the legally binding signing of a Brexit withdrawal treaty. (Times) Open Europe, a think tank with close ties to prominent Brexiteers, says today that the UK should in effect become a “rule-taker” on regulations over goods while building its own rules on services. (Times)

DUP’s Foster has threatened to withdraw from the alliance pact with the Conservatives if UK PM May takes up a Brexit deal that treats Northern Ireland differently to the rest of the UK. (Belfast Telegraph) Internally for May, the UK PM faces a rebellion by Foreign Minister Johnson and other leading Tory MPs amid reports that she is considering a potential vote for a third runway at Heathrow later this month. (Telegraph)

UK government is said to be taking an active role in determining VAT regulations for the 2020s according to a minister, which reports state suggests UK could be seeking to remain inside the EU 'VAT area' post-Brexit. (FT)

UK Markit/CIPS Construction PMI (May) 52.5 vs. Exp. 51.9 (Prev. 52.5) (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Reports suggested North Korea could have faked detonation of its nuclear test site last month, as it cited dust from explosions and journalists being 500 metres from the explosion which indicates small blasts. (Axios)

US officials reported that North Korea’s top three military officials have been replaced. (CNBC)

Syrian President Assad plans to visit North Korea to meet with Kim Jong Un. (KCNA)

 

EQUITIES

European equities are positive (Stoxx 600 +0.6%) as markets continue to digest Friday's NFP report and the rescheduling of the NK-US summit on June 12th, thus outweighing the lingering trade concerns which saw the US and China fail to reach an agreement over the weekend, albeit both parties stated that progress had been made.

The IBEX (+1.8%) is the outperformer amid positivity on the domestic political front.

The FTSE MIB is fluctuating between positive and negative as political uncertainty in the region is leading to volatile trade.

Utilities are currently outperforming with Iberdrola leading the sector (+3.3%) after an upgrade at Goldman Sachs.

M&A news is in focus, primarily with Accor’s interest in an Air France KLM (+7.0%) stake. Additionally Bayer announced a EUR 6bln cash call for the June 7thMonsanto acquisition. Finally, there were rumblings that Unicredit (+0.5%) and SocGen (+2.0%) were considering a merger; this was denied by SocGen, however.

 

FX

AUD

The clear G10 outperformer on several bullish/supportive factors, including overnight data in the form of retail sales, company profits and Q1 business inventories that all exceeded expectations. Coupled with broadly risk-on sentiment on the back of Friday’s upbeat US jobs report and geopolitical news (June 12 summit between US and NK back on track), which offset another US-China summit ending without anything tangible in terms of import tariff trade-offs, Aud/Usd has finally established a firmer foothold above 0.7600 and breached chart resistance through 0.7605-13 incorporating the 50 DMA (0.7610). Aud buyers are now testing 0.7643-60 that encompasses a key Fib and a chart channel, but the bout of strength may not be greeted with enthusiasm by the RBA on Tuesday given recent policy statements highlighting the adverse impact of a strong currency on the growth, wage and inflation outlook. Note, the latest GDP update follows hot on the heels of the RBA policy meeting on Wednesday.

NZD

The Kiwi is just holding off the Eur and Cad as 2nd best major vs the Usd, and largely on the coat-tails of its antipodean counterpart as Nzd/Usd regains 0.7000+ status, but Aud/Nzd bounces firmly towards 1.0900.

EUR/CAD

As noted above, both firmer vs the Greenback with the single currency re-testing recent highs above 1.1700 in wake of some clarity on the Italian and Spanish political fronts, while the Loonie continues to benefit from last week’s more upbeat BoC economic assessments and less cautious policy guidance that has overshadowed much weaker than forecast Q1 GDP annualised growth. Usd/Cad hovering just above 1.2900 vs last week’s circa 1.3000 peak.

GBP/CHF

Also gaining at the expense of the Dollar with Cable around 1.3380, and the Franc at the lower end of a 0.9835-95 range. Note,  no immediate reaction in the Pound to another UK PMI beat as the construction headline was tainted by a contraction in new orders, but Cable did subsequently test 1.3400 before easing back again.

JPY

Usd/Jpy nearer the base of a 109.45-75 band, with offers seen above 109.90 according to market observers and big option expiries also keeping the headline pair in check (1.7 bn at the 110.00 strike vs 1.4 bn between 108.90-109.05).

DXY

The index is pivoting 94.000 having failed to derive any lasting benefit from Friday’s strong NFP release, as the key wage component continues to lag.

SEK/NOK

Both outpacing the Eur on recent firm Scandi data that supports more hawkish Riksbank and Norges Bank rate outlooks vs the ECB, but the Nok may be hampered somewhat by bearish seasonals and tight liquidity constraints per Nordea.

TRY

Off worst levels prompted by Moody’s ratings downgrade alert for Turkey as a pick up in inflations underpins CBRT rate hike prospects for this Thursday. Usd/Try near the base of 4.6780-5940 trading parameters.

 

FIXED INCOME

More stop-tripping in Bunds it seems, but this time on the downside through 161.00 at the latest time of asking, then again once the 10 year benchmark breached 160.95 (pre-NFP session low) to 160.87, -59 ticks on the day and coinciding (almost exactly) with a Fib level. Turning to fundamentals, the further advance in BTPs through 130.00 and a fair resistance point at 130.20 to 130.28 has weighed heavier on Bunds while position-rolling from June to September continues.

 

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.7%) and Brent (-1.4%) prices have thus far failed to significantly rebound from the losses seen at the back end of last week after shedding more than 9.9% from the multi-year high levels, while the unofficial OPEC+ meeting during the weekend also continued to signal an unwillingness to ease restrictions. Prices were also subdued by the weekly Baker Hughes rig count showing an increase of 2 oil rig.

Elsewhere, gold (+0.1%) is uneventful while shanghai copper hits highs of more than six weeks, underpinned by a marginally softer dollar and labour negotiations at the world’s largest copper mine. Dalian iron ore however fell almost 2% as it moved in tandem with steel prices amid the iron ore stockpiles at China’s port surging to record levels.

EU MID SESSION UPDATE: European markets continue Friday's rally, overlooking ongoing trade fears
content:
EQUITIES

European equities are positive (Stoxx 600 +0.5%) as markets continue to digest Friday's NFP report and the rescheduling of the NK-US summit on June 12th, thus outweighing the lingering trade concerns which saw the US and China fail to reach an agreement over the weekend, albeit both parties stated that progress had been made.

The IBEX (+1.2%) is the outperformer amid positivity on the domestic political front.

The FTSE MIB is fluctuating between positive and negative as political uncertainty in the region is leading to volatile trade.

Utilities are currently outperforming with Iberdrola leading the sector (+3.0%) after an upgrade at Goldman Sachs.

M&A news is in focus, primarily with Accor’s interest in an Air France KLM (+6.5%) stake. Additionally Bayer announced a EUR 6bln cash call for the June 7thMonsanto acquisition. Finally there were rumblings that Unicredit (+0.7%) and SocGen (+1.7%) were considering a merger; this was denied by SocGen, however.

COMMODITIES

WTI (flat%) and Brent (-0.2%) prices have thus far failed to significantly rebound from the losses seen at the back end of last week after shedding more than 9.9% from the multi-year high levels, while the unofficial OPEC+ meeting during the weekend also continued to signal an unwillingness to ease restrictions. Prices were also subdued by the weekly Baker Hughes rig count showing an increase of 2 oil rig.

Elsewhere, gold (flat) is uneventful while shanghai copper hits highs of more than six weeks, underpinned by a marginally softer dollar and labour negotiations at the world’s largest copper mine. Dalian iron ore however fell almost 2% as it moved in tandem with steel prices amid the iron ore stockpiles at China’s port surging to record levels.

FX

AUD

The clear G10 outperformer on several bullish/supportive factors, including overnight data in the form of retail sales, company profits and Q1 business inventories that all exceeded expectations. Coupled with broadly risk-on sentiment on the back of Friday’s upbeat US jobs report and geopolitical news (June 12 summit between US and NK back on track), which offset another US-China summit ending without anything tangible in terms of import tariff trade-offs, Aud/Usd has finally established a firmer foothold above 0.7600 and breached chart resistance through 0.7605-13 incorporating the 50 DMA (0.7610). Aud buyers are now eyeing 0.7643-60 that encompasses a key Fib and a chart channel, but the bout of strength may not be greeted with enthusiasm by the RBA on Tuesday given recent policy statements highlighting the adverse impact of a strong currency on the growth, wage and inflation outlook. Note, the latest GDP update follows hot on the heels of the RBA policy meeting on Wednesday.

NZD 

The Kiwi is just holding off the Eur and Cad as 2nd best major vs the Usd, and largely on the coat-tails of its antipodean counterpart as Nzd/Usd regains 0.7000+ status, but Aud/Nzd bounces firmly towards 1.0900.

EUR/CAD

As noted above, both firmer vs the Greenback with the single currency re-testing recent highs above 1.1700 in wake of some clarity on the Italian and Spanish political fronts, while the Loonie continues to benefit from last week’s more upbeat BoC economic assessments and less cautious policy guidance that has overshadowed much weaker than forecast Q1 GDP annualised growth. Usd/Cad hovering just above 1.2900 vs last week’s circa 1.3000 peak.

GBP/CHF/JPY 

All pretty flat vs the Dollar with Cable around 1.3360, the Franc in the middle of a 0.9855-95 range and Usd/Jpy nearer the base of a 109.45-75 band, with offers seen above 109.90 according to market observers and big option expiries also keeping the headline pair in check (1.7 bn at the 110.00 strike vs 1.4 bn between 108.90-109.05). Back to the Pound, no reaction to another UK PMI beat as the construction headline was tainted by a contraction in new orders.

DXY

The index is pivoting 94.000 having failed to derive any lasting benefit from Friday’s strong NFP release, as the key wage component continues to lag.

SEK/NOK

Both outpacing the Eur on recent firm Scandi data that supports more hawkish Riksbank and Norges Bank rate outlooks vs the ECB, but the Nok may be hampered somewhat by bearish seasonals and tight liquidity constraints per Nordea.

TRY

Off worst levels prompted by Moody’s ratings downgrade alert for Turkey as a pick up in inflations underpins CBRT rate hike prospects for this Thursday. Usd/Try near the base of 4.6780-5940 trading parameters.

FIXED INCOME

Fresh lows and highs for core bonds, but ultimately no game changing moves as Bunds and Gilts move back within the trading parameters carved out thus far. The 10 year German debt future held just above 161.00 at 161.02 before bouncing quite firmly to 161.42 with the aid of some intraday stops once the previous session peak was breached (161.33). Meanwhile, Gilts stretched their Liffe best to 122.95, but could not seriously challenge 123.00 and then reversed on another UK PMI beat, albeit with new orders contracting again and nullifying the firm headline to an extent. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are hugging overnight session lows and steepening somewhat after Friday’s post-NFP bear curve flattening, as the focus shifts to factory orders.

UK debt and STIR futures: correcting lower ahead of UK construction PMI
content: Gilts are tracking core debt counterparts off Monday’s Liffe open within a 122.63-82 range vs last week’s 122.91 close amidst largely risk-on trade, but the Short Sterling strip is holding up relatively well in line with Euribor futures on contrasting near term policy outlooks between the BoE/ECB and Fed that looks guaranteed to hike rates again next week. In terms of UK-specific drivers, May’s construction PMI could be a market mover, while after hours BoE’s Tenreyro is due to speak and may touch upon the economy and/or policy.

subject: Spanish PM Sanchez is to have the cabinet ready in two to three days

Morning EU Movers: Air France (AF FP) +6.2%, UniCredit (UCG IM) +3.5%, Lufthansa (LHA GY) +2.5%, SocGen (GLE FP) +2.3%, FTSE MIB +1.2%, Accor (AC FP) -1.5%
Bunds: testing support and bidding interest ahead of 161.00
content: The 10 year German benchmark is succumbing to more safe-haven unwinding on several fronts, including further reaction to Friday’s broadly better than expected US jobs data, another rebound in BTPs following the formation of Italy’s new Government coalition and reports that June 12’s US-NK summit will go ahead as planned. Bunds gapped down 22 ticks initially to 161.24 and subsequently hit an early 161.04 low before finding some underlying support ahead of the big figure, recent lows and a key Fib just below 161.00. Ahead, a relatively quiet start to the week on the Eurozone data front with just Sentix and PPI on tap, but ECB’s Nowotny is scheduled to speak and the latest QE tallies may make interesting reading as they include more detailed member state asset purchase totals for the month of May when Italian bonds were subject to extreme investor angst until the aforementioned political breakthrough in Rome.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

4th June 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week higher across the board as the region got a double-dose of optimism from stronger than expected US NFP jobs data and after US President Trump confirmed the summit with North Korea will go ahead as initially planned in Singapore on June 12th. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) were both positive from the get-go with CYBG shares leading the advances in Australia after the Co. sweetened its merger bid for Virgin Money, while the Japanese benchmark was among the outperformers as it coat-tails on a weaker currency. Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) also conformed to the broad upbeat sentiment following a net liquidity injection by the PBoC and amid reports that China widened the collateral for its Medium-term Lending Facility which will include qualified credit bonds. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid a similar performance in T-notes and with demand subdued by risk appetite, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement also failed to support as the central bank maintained its purchase amounts across the curve.

FTSE

BT (BT/A LN) – The co. CEO Patterson is under pressure from top stakeholders after shares are at record lows, he’s is stated to be on his “last chance”. (FT)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – The co.’s outgoing CEO has had his pay increase to GBP 8mln this year vs. GBP 6.3mln previously. (FT)

BHP Billiton (BLT LN) – The co.’s exit from US shale has drawn oil and PE companies into a competition that could have no clear winners until late this year or next year, according to people close to the negotiations. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co.’s Moxetumomab Pasudotox met primary endpoint of durable complete response. (Newswires)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – The co., as well as Nisa and Aldi, have had pastries recalled because of the possibility of metal wire within them. (BBC)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

CYBG (CYBG LN) – The co. has raised its offer for Virgin Money by offering Virgin shareholders larger stake holdings in the combined company. (FT)

Dixons Carphone (DC/ LN) – The co. is stated to be losing at least on large mobile network from its business after trying to squeeze more money out of the telecoms industry. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

GVC (GVC LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM ADD AT ALPHAVALUE AND UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – The co. has announced a EUR 6bln cash call in order to finance its EUR 66bln takeover of Monsanto (FT)

German Steel names – The countries competition regulator is in talks with the steel industry over fines totalling EUR 500mln over antitrust violations. (Newswires)

Linde (LIN GY) – Antitrust concerns have been outlined for the Linde/Praxair merger. (FT)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – A large shareholder in the co. has called the situation serious and worrying. (Handelsblatt)

Deutsche Lufthansa (LHA GY) – CEO states that their reduced capacity plan will lead to an improvement in summer yields. (Newswires)

Siemens (SIE GY) / Siemens Healthineers (SHL GY) – Siemens has said it will keep a stake in the recently listed Healthineers in the long-term. (Newswires)

CAC

Accor (AC FP) – The co. is considering buying a stake in Air France KLM (AF FP). (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – The co. has dismissed concerns over a fall in A330neo orders, and predicted a recovery in demand this year. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Ipsen (IPN FP) – Co. has initiated a share repurchase program to finance its free share allocation and employee share plans. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

HERMES (RMS FP) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – Two oncology drugs only provided a modest protection from disease progression in lung and breast cancer, according to clinical trials. (Newswires)

Richemont (CFR SW) – The co. has bought the UK based company Watchfinder for an undisclosed sum. (FT)

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Announces positive results for third Phase III trial of Kisqali. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

PANDORA (PNDORA DC) DOWNGRADED TO SECTOR PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT RBC

PAN EUROPE

Unicredit (UCG IM) / /SocGen (GLE FP) – Unicredit is exploring a merger with Société Générale, however no formal approach has been made. (FT)

UCB (UCB BB) – The co. has seen CHMP positive opinion for adjunctive use of Briviact. (Newswires)

Saipem (SPM IM) – The co. has won a pipeline contract from Qatargas valued at more than USD 1bln. (Il Sole 24 Ore)

Banca Monte Dei Paschi (BMPS IM) – the co. is planning to sell about EUR 2bln of unsecured loans, which will start in September. (Il Sole 24 Ore)

Unilever (UNA NA) – The co. has rebranded its personal care division to include beauty products as part of that section. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

INTESA SANPAOLO (ISP IM) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

UBI BANCA (UBI IM) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

US

*EQUITIES: SPX +1.07% at 2734 , NDX +1.67% at 7084, DJI +0.89% at 24633.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.70%, Cons Non-Cyclicals:-0.03%, Energy: +0.50%, Financials: +1.1%%, Health Care: +1.2%, Industrials: +1.2%, Materials: +1.5%, Telecom: +0.2%, Tech: +2.00%, Utilities: -1.5%

US Equity futures benefitted from a risk-on tone on Friday, as political tensions eased in Europe. The constructive risk environment saw the S&P 500 Emini grinding higher through the course of the session, despite a slight dip following the US jobs report; however, downticks were fleeting and the futures resumed ricking higher through the course of the session, breaking the key 2730 level but finding resistance just shy of 2740 where selling was observed.

subject: Major FX option expiries for today's NY cut
RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 4th June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week higher across the board as the region reacted to Friday’s US jobs report and the US-NK summit being back on the cards
  • In FX markets, safe-havens were under strain in which JPY took the brunt of the heightened risk appetite which saw USD/JPY and JPY-crosses extend on Friday’s gains
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK construction PMI, US factory orders and BoE’s Tenreyro

 

TRADE

US Commerce Secretary Ross travelled to Beijing the past weekend for the 3rd round of trade talks with China which ended without a deal. However, there were comments by Ross that meetings were friendly and frank, while China commented that they have made concrete progress but warned any action by US to impose punitive tariffs would derail the negotiations. (Newswires)

US President Trump said on Friday that he would be open to having separate trade deals with Canada and Mexico. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow stated that Canadian PM Trudeau’s response to the US tariffs on steel and aluminium was an overreaction, while he added the tariffs may last a while or not which is subject to negotiations and that he views the issue as more of a family quarrel. (Newswires)

Canada launched WTO and NAFTA cases on US metal tariffs. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week higher across the board as the region got a double-dose of optimism from stronger than expected US NFP jobs data and after US President Trump confirmed the summit with North Korea will go ahead as initially planned in Singapore on June 12th. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) were both positive from the get-go with CYBG shares leading the advances in Australia after the Co. sweetened its merger bid for Virgin Money, while the Japanese benchmark was among the outperformers as it coat-tails on a weaker currency. Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) also conformed to the broad upbeat sentiment following a net liquidity injection by the PBoC and amid reports that China widened the collateral for its Medium-term Lending Facility which will include qualified credit bonds. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid a similar performance in T-notes and with demand subdued by risk appetite, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement also failed to support as the central bank maintained its purchase amounts across the curve.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day and CNY 20bln via 28-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4208 (Prev. 6.4078)
 

UK/EU

Britain will have only weeks to negotiate deals with dozens of countries after the European Union denied help to extend any existing trade agreements before the legally binding signing of a Brexit withdrawal treaty. (Times) Open Europe, a think tank with close ties to prominent Brexiteers, says today that the UK should in effect become a “rule-taker” on regulations over goods while building its own rules on services. (Times)

DUP’s Foster has threatened to withdraw from the alliance pact with the Conservatives if UK PM May takes up a Brexit deal that treats Northern Ireland differently to the rest of the UK. (Belfast Telegraph) Internally for May, the UK PM faces a rebellion by Foreign Minister Johnson and other leading Tory MPs amid reports that she is considering a potential vote for a third runway at Heathrow later this month. (Telegraph)

UK government is said to be taking an active role in determining VAT regulations for the 2020s according to a minister, which reports state suggests UK could be seeking to remain inside the EU 'VAT area' post-Brexit. (FT)

German Chancellor Merkel said stabilizing stabilising euro requires banking and capital markets union, while she added instruments at disposal are not sufficient to sustainably stabilize euro. (Newswires)

ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said direct impact on US tariffs on the EU economy are limited but noted that trade wars are a large risk for economic development. (Newswires)

The new Catalan government took office which automatically lifted Madrid direct rule for the region, while the new Catalan government head Quim Torra stated they are committed to independence. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Ireland at 'A+/A-1'; outlook stable, while Fitch Affirmed Belgium at 'AA-'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Portugal at 'BBB'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, safe-havens were under strain in which JPY took the brunt of the heightened risk appetite which saw USD/JPY and JPY-crosses extend on Friday’s gains, while the greenback was also softer overnight to the benefit of its major counterparts across the pond with EUR/USD and GBP/USD taking advantage of the DXY’s retreat towards the 94.00 level. Elsewhere, antipodeans also took their swipe at the USD in which NZD/USD reclaimed the 0.7000 handle to the upside and with AUD underpinned by better than expected Retail Sales data as it kicks-start an eventful week which includes the RBA policy meeting tomorrow and GDP data on Wednesday. Furthermore, some also suggested strong Australian Company profits and Business Inventories could be viewed as encouraging for the upcoming GDP release.

Australian Retail Sales MM (Apr) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.0%). (Newswires)
Australian Gross Operating Company Profits (Q1) 5.9% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 2.2%)
Australian Business Inventories (Q1) 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.2%)


COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures languished overnight following the pullback observed in the past 2 weeks with prices rapidly approaching correction territory other shedding more than 9.9% from the multi-year high levels seen in last month, while the unofficial OPEC+ meeting during the weekend also continued to signal an unwillingness to ease restrictions. Elsewhere, gold was uneventful and copper was marginally higher as the heightened risk appetite sapped safe-haven demand, but underpinned prices in the latter.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (25 May) 1060 (Prev. 1059). (Newswires)

OPEC and non-OPEC ministers met in Kuwait in an unofficial meeting on Saturday in which they stressed the need to maintain the current cooperation and continue with successful efforts carried out by the participating countries. (Newswires)

Motiva have ruled out doubling capacity at their US refinery amid hurricane fears. (Newswires) Note, this refinery is the largest in the US with an output capacity of 600,000bpd

GEOPOLITICS


US President Trump said the meeting with North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un is back on which is to take place in Singapore on June 12th and noted the North Koreans want to denuclearise, while there were also reports that US President trump does not want to use the term ‘Maximum pressure’ as they are getting along with North Korea. (Newswires)

Reports suggested North Korea could have faked detonation of its nuclear test site last month, as it cited dust from explosions and journalists being 500 metres from the explosion which indicates small blasts. (Axios)

US officials reported that North Korea’s top three military officials have been replaced. (CNBC)

Syrian President Assad plans to visit North Korea to meet with Kim Jong Un. (KCNA)
 

US

The Treasury complex was under pressure for most of Friday, along with decent volume, as political tensions in Europe eased, a decent NFP report, and news that the summit with North Korea is back on. However, although yields were higher across the curve by between 6-8bps, major curves continued to narrow, with 2s30s over 2bps narrower, and 5s30s flatter by around the same margin; 2s5s was relatively unchanged. US 10yr T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled 19 ticks lower at 119-27.

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said Fed should continue with gradual hikes over the upcoming two years and that he expects US rates to be neutral after three more hikes. Furthermore, Williams also stated the Fed should not necessarily pause once it reaches neutral if economy remains firm. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: US and China held a 3rd round of trade talks over the weekend
content:
Esprit Holdings (330 HK)
- Co. names Anders Christian Kristiansen as its new CEO with immediate effect. (Newswires)

Future Land Development (1030 HK)
- Co. Chairman reportedly acquired 1.7mln shares in the Co. (Newswires)

Jiangzhong Pharmaceutical (600750 CH)
- China Resources Group is to make an offer of CNY 25.03/Share with a maximum value of CNY 4.28bln. (Newswires)

SouthGobi Resources (763 HK)
- Co. names new CEO and CFO with immediate effect. (Newswires)

ZTE (763 HK)
- US President Trump's administration reportedly might claim a USD 1.7bln penalty against ZTE, as two sides discuss removing the commerce ban, according to sources. (Newswires)

Trade / Geopolitics
- US Commerce Secretary Ross travelled to Beijing the past weekend for the 3rd round of trade talks with China which ended without a deal. However, there were comments by Ross that the meetings were friendly and frank, while China commented that they have made concrete progress and that any action by US to impose punitive tariffs would derail the negotiations. (Newswires)
- China is willing to expand imports from multiple countries including US, according to press reports. (Xinhua)
- US Secretary of Defence Mattis accuses China of intimidation and coercion in South China Sea and suggests consequences if this continues. (Newswires)

Property
- China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission said insurance funds are to be permitted to invest in long-term housing rental projects. (Xinhua)

Other News
- PBoC stated it conducted CNY 34.8bln of Standing Lending Facility, CNY 150.6bln of Medium-term Lending Facility and CNY 80.1bln in Pledged Supplementary Lending during May. (Newswires)
- PBoC widened the collateral for its Medium-term Lending Facility and will include qualified credit bonds. (Newswires)
- China tightened rules on money market funds by capping same-day redemption at USD 1560 for a single fund. (SCMP)
- China Q2 growth is expected at between 6.7%-6.8%, according to Chinese press commentary. (China Daily)
